text: Then the Lord called to Moses and spoke to him from the Meeting Tent:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When someone among you presents an offering to the Lord, you must present your offering from the domesticated animals, either from the herd or from the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering is a burnt offering from the herd he must present it as a flawless male; he must present it at the entrance of the Meeting Tent for its acceptance before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of the burnt offering, and it will be accepted for him to make atonement on his behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one presenting the offering must slaughter the bull before the Lord, and the sons of Aaron, the priests, must present the blood and splash the blood against the sides of the altar, which is at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, the one presenting the offering must skin the burnt offering and cut it into parts,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sons of Aaron, the priest, must put fire on the altar and arrange wood on the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sons of Aaron, the priests, must arrange the parts with the head and the suet on the wood that is in the fire on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the one presenting the offering must wash its entrails and its legs in water and the priest must offer all of it up in smoke on the altar—it is a burnt offering, a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering is from the flock for a burnt offering—from the sheep or the goats—he must present a flawless male,
speaker: Narrator

text: and must slaughter it on the north side of the altar before the Lord, and the sons of Aaron, the priests, will splash its blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, the one presenting the offering must cut it into parts, with its head and its suet, and the priest must arrange them on the wood that is in the fire on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one presenting the offering must wash the entrails and the legs in water, and the priest must present all of it and offer it up in smoke on the altar—it is a burnt offering, a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering to the Lord is a burnt offering of birds, he must present his offering from the turtledoves or from the young pigeons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must present it at the altar, pinch off its head and offer the head up in smoke on the altar, and its blood must be drained out against the side of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must remove its entrails by cutting off its tail feathers, and throw them to the east side of the altar into the place of fatty ashes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and tear it open by its wings without dividing it into two parts. Finally, the priest must offer it up in smoke on the altar on the wood which is in the fire—it is a burnt offering, a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a person presents a grain offering to the Lord, his offering must consist of choice wheat flour, and he must pour olive oil on it and put frankincense on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must bring it to the sons of Aaron, the priests, and the priest must scoop out from there a handful of its choice wheat flour and some of its olive oil in addition to all of its frankincense, and the priest must offer its memorial portion up in smoke on the altar—it is a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remainder of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and to his sons—it is most holy from the gifts of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you present an offering of grain baked in an oven, it must be made of choice wheat flour baked into unleavened loaves mixed with olive oil or unleavened wafers smeared with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your offering is a grain offering made on the griddle, it must be choice wheat flour mixed with olive oil, unleavened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crumble it in pieces and pour olive oil on it—it is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your offering is a grain offering made in a pan, it must be made of choice wheat flour deep fried in olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must bring the grain offering that must be made from these to the Lord. Present it to the priest, and he will bring it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must take up from the grain offering its memorial portion and offer it up in smoke on the altar—it is a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remainder of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and to his sons—it is most holy from the gifts of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘No grain offering which you present to the Lord can be made with yeast, for you must not offer up in smoke any yeast or honey as a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can present them to the Lord as an offering of firstfruit, but they must not go up to the altar for a soothing aroma.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you must season every one of your grain offerings with salt; you must not allow the salt of the covenant of your God to be missing from your grain offering—on every one of your grain offerings you must present salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If you present a grain offering of first ripe grain to the Lord, you must present your grain offering of first ripe grain as soft kernels roasted in fire—crushed bits of fresh grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must put olive oil on it and set frankincense on it—it is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must offer its memorial portion up in smoke—some of its crushed bits, some of its olive oil, in addition to all of its frankincense—it is a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now if his offering is a peace-offering sacrifice, if he presents an offering from the herd, he must present before the Lord a flawless male or a female.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of his offering and slaughter it at the entrance of the Meeting Tent, and the sons of Aaron, the priests, must splash the blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one presenting the offering must present a gift to the Lord from the peace-offering sacrifice: He must remove the fat that covers the entrails and all the fat that surrounds the entrails,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two kidneys with the fat on their sinews, and the protruding lobe on the liver (which he is to remove along with the kidneys).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sons of Aaron must offer it up in smoke on the altar atop the burnt offering that is on the wood in the fire as a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering for a peace-offering sacrifice to the Lord is from the flock, he must present a flawless male or female.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he presents a sheep as his offering, he must present it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of his offering and slaughter it before the Meeting Tent, and the sons of Aaron must splash its blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must present a gift to the Lord from the peace-offering sacrifice: He must remove all the fatty tail up to the end of the spine, the fat covering the entrails, and all the fat on the entrails,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two kidneys with the fat on their sinews, and the protruding lobe on the liver (which he is to remove along with the kidneys).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must offer it up in smoke on the altar as a food gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering is a goat he must present it before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: lay his hand on its head, and slaughter it before the Meeting Tent, and the sons of Aaron must splash its blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must present from it his offering as a gift to the Lord: the fat which covers the entrails and all the fat on the entrails,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two kidneys with the fat on their sinews, and the protruding lobe on the liver (which he is to remove along with the kidneys).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must offer them up in smoke on the altar as a food gift for a soothing aroma—all the fat belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all the places where you live: You must never eat any fat or any blood.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘When a person sins by straying unintentionally from any of the Lord’s commandments which must not be violated, and violates any one of them—
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If the high priest sins so that the people are guilty, on account of the sin he has committed he must present a flawless young bull to the Lord for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring the bull to the entrance of the Meeting Tent before the Lord, lay his hand on the head of the bull, and slaughter the bull before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then that high priest must take some of the blood of the bull and bring it to the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must dip his finger in the blood and sprinkle some of it seven times before the Lord toward the front of the special curtain of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of fragrant incense that is before the Lord in the Meeting Tent, and all the rest of the bull’s blood he must pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering that is at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then he must take up all the fat from the sin offering bull: the fat covering the entrails and all the fat surrounding the entrails,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two kidneys with the fat on their sinews, and the protruding lobe on the liver (which he is to remove along with the kidneys)
speaker: Narrator

text: —just as it is taken from the ox of the peace-offering sacrifice—and the priest must offer them up in smoke on the altar of burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hide of the bull, all its flesh along with its head and its legs, its entrails, and its dung—
speaker: Narrator

text: all the rest of the bull—he must bring outside the camp to a ceremonially clean place, to the fatty-ash pile, and he must burn it on a wood fire; it must be burned on the fatty-ash pile.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If the whole congregation of Israel strays unintentionally and the matter is not noticed by the assembly, and they violate one of the Lord’s commandments, which must not be violated, so they become guilty,
speaker: Narrator

text: the assembly must present a young bull for a sin offering when the sin they have committed becomes known. They must bring it before the Meeting Tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the elders of the congregation must lay their hands on the head of the bull before the Lord, and someone must slaughter the bull before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priest must bring some of the blood of the bull to the Meeting Tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that priest must dip his finger in the blood and sprinkle some of the blood seven times before the Lord toward the front of the curtain.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must put some of the blood on the horns of the altar which is before the Lord in the Meeting Tent, and all the rest of the blood he must pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering that is at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then the priest must take all its fat and offer the fat up in smoke on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must do with the rest of the bull just as he did with the bull of the sin offering; this is what he must do with it. So the priest will make atonement on their behalf and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring the rest of the bull outside the camp and burn it just as he burned the first bull—it is the sin offering of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Whenever a leader, by straying unintentionally, sins and violates one of the commandments of the Lord his God which must not be violated, and he pleads guilty,
speaker: Narrator

text: or his sin that he committed is made known to him, he must bring a flawless male goat as his offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of the male goat and slaughter it in the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered before the Lord—it is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and he must pour out the rest of its blood at the base of the altar of burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must offer all of its fat up in smoke on the altar like the fat of the peace-offering sacrifice. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf for his sin and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If an ordinary individual sins by straying unintentionally when he violates one of the Lord’s commandments which must not be violated, and he pleads guilty,
speaker: Narrator

text: or his sin that he committed is made known to him, he must bring a flawless female goat as his offering for the sin that he committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter the sin offering in the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must take some of its blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and he must pour out all the rest of its blood at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must remove all of its fat (just as fat was removed from the peace-offering sacrifice) and the priest must offer it up in smoke on the altar for a soothing aroma to the Lord. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But if he brings a sheep as his offering, for a sin offering, he must bring a flawless female.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter it for a sin offering in the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and he must pour out all the rest of its blood at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one who brought the offering must remove all its fat (just as the fat of the sheep is removed from the peace-offering sacrifice) and the priest must offer them up in smoke on the altar on top of the other gifts for the Lord. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf for his sin which he has committed and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a person sins in that he hears a public curse against one who fails to testify and he is a witness (he either saw or knew what had happened) and he does not make it known, then he will bear his punishment for iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or when there is a person who touches anything ceremonially unclean, whether the carcass of an unclean wild animal, or the carcass of an unclean domesticated animal, or the carcass of an unclean creeping thing, even if he did not realize it, he has become unclean and is guilty;
speaker: Narrator

text: or when he touches human uncleanness with regard to anything by which he can become unclean, even if he did not realize it, but he has later come to know it and is guilty;
speaker: Narrator

text: or when a person swears an oath, speaking thoughtlessly with his lips, whether to do evil or to do good, with regard to anything which the individual might speak thoughtlessly in an oath, even if he did not realize it, but he has later come to know it and is guilty with regard to one of these oaths—
speaker: Narrator

text: when an individual becomes guilty with regard to one of these things he must confess how he has sinned,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he must bring his penalty for guilt to the Lord for his sin that he has committed—a female from the flock, whether a female sheep or a female goat, for a sin offering. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf for his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If he cannot afford an animal from the flock, he must bring his penalty for guilt for his sin that he has committed, two turtledoves or two young pigeons, to the Lord, one for a sin offering and one for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring them to the priest and present first the one that is for a sin offering. The priest must pinch its head at the nape of its neck, but must not sever the head from the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must sprinkle some of the blood of the sin offering on the wall of the altar, and the remainder of the blood must be squeezed out at the base of the altar—it is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second bird he must make a burnt offering according to the standard regulation. So the priest will make atonement on behalf of this person for his sin which he has committed, and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If he cannot afford two turtledoves or two young pigeons, he must bring as his offering for his sin which he has committed a tenth of an ephah of choice wheat flour for a sin offering. He must not place olive oil on it, and he must not put frankincense on it, because it is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring it to the priest, and the priest must scoop out from it a handful as its memorial portion and offer it up in smoke on the altar on top of the other gifts of the Lord—it is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest will make atonement on his behalf for his sin which he has committed by doing one of these things, and he will be forgiven. The remainder of the offering will belong to the priest like the grain offering.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a person commits a trespass and sins by straying unintentionally from the regulations about the Lord’s holy things, then he must bring his penalty for guilt to the Lord, a flawless ram from the flock, convertible into silver shekels according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel, for a guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whatever holy thing he violated he must restore and must add one-fifth to it and give it to the priest. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf with the guilt-offering ram and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a person sins and violates any of the Lord’s commandments that must not be violated (although he did not know it at the time, but later realizes he is guilty), then he will bear his punishment for iniquity
speaker: Narrator

text: and must bring a flawless ram from the flock, convertible into silver shekels, for a guilt offering to the priest. So the priest will make atonement on his behalf for his error that he committed (although he himself had not known it) and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a guilt offering; he was surely guilty before the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (5:20) Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a person sins and commits a trespass against the Lord by deceiving his fellow citizen in regard to something held in trust, or a pledge, or something stolen, or by extorting something from his fellow citizen,
speaker: Narrator

text: or has found something lost and denies it and swears falsely concerning any one of the things that someone might do to sin—
speaker: Narrator

text: when it happens that he sins and he is found guilty then he must return whatever he had stolen, or whatever he had extorted, or the thing that he had held in trust, or the lost thing that he had found,
speaker: Narrator

text: or anything about which he swears falsely. He must restore it in full and add one-fifth to it; he must give it to its owner when he is found guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must bring his guilt offering to the Lord, a flawless ram from the flock, convertible into silver shekels, for a guilt offering to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest will make atonement on his behalf before the Lord and he will be forgiven for whatever he has done to become guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (6:1) Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command Aaron and his sons, ‘This is the law of the burnt offering. The burnt offering is to remain on the hearth on the altar all night until morning, and the fire of the altar must be kept burning on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must put on his linen robe and must put linen leggings over his bare flesh, and he must take up the fatty ashes of the burnt offering that the fire consumed on the altar, and he must place them beside the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must take off his clothes and put on other clothes, and he must bring the fatty ashes outside the camp to a ceremonially clean place,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the fire which is on the altar must be kept burning on it. It must not be extinguished. So the priest must kindle wood on it morning by morning, and he must arrange the burnt offering on it and offer the fat of the peace offering up in smoke on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A continual fire must be kept burning on the altar. It must not be extinguished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the law of the grain offering. The sons of Aaron are to present it before the Lord in front of the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest must take up with his hand some of the choice wheat flour of the grain offering and some of its olive oil, and all of the frankincense that is on the grain offering, and he must offer its memorial portion up in smoke on the altar as a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons are to eat what is left over from it. It must be eaten unleavened in a holy place; they are to eat it in the courtyard of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must not be baked with yeast. I have given it as their portion from my gifts. It is most holy, like the sin offering and the guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every male among the sons of Aaron may eat it. It is a perpetual allotted portion throughout your generations from the gifts of the Lord. Anyone who touches these gifts must be holy.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the offering of Aaron and his sons which they must present to the Lord on the day when he is anointed: a tenth of an ephah of choice wheat flour as a continual grain offering, half of it in the morning and half of it in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be made with olive oil on a griddle and you must bring it well soaked, so you must present a grain offering of broken pieces as a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest who succeeds him from among his sons must do it. It is a perpetual statute; it must be offered up in smoke as a whole offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering of a priest must be a whole offering; it must not be eaten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons, ‘This is the law of the sin offering. In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered the sin offering must be slaughtered before the Lord. It is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who offers it for sin is to eat it. It must be eaten in a holy place, in the courtyard of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches its meat must be holy, and whoever spatters some of its blood on a garment must wash whatever he spatters it on in a holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any clay vessel it is boiled in must be broken, and if it was boiled in a bronze vessel, then that vessel must be rubbed out and rinsed in water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male among the priests may eat it. It is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any sin offering from which some of its blood is brought into the Meeting Tent to make atonement in the sanctuary must not be eaten. It must be burned up in the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the law of the guilt offering. It is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the place where they slaughter the burnt offering they must slaughter the guilt offering, and the officiating priest must splash the blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one making the offering must present all its fat: the fatty tail, the fat covering the entrails,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two kidneys and the fat on their sinews, and the protruding lobe on the liver (which he must remove along with the kidneys).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must offer them up in smoke on the altar as a gift to the Lord. It is a guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male among the priests may eat it. It must be eaten in a holy place. It is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The law is the same for the sin offering and the guilt offering; it belongs to the priest who makes atonement with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As for the priest who presents someone’s burnt offering, the hide of that burnt offering which he presented belongs to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering which is baked in the oven or made in the pan or on the griddle belongs to the priest who presented it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering, whether mixed with olive oil or dry, belongs to all the sons of Aaron, each one alike.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the law of the peace-offering sacrifice which he is to present to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he presents it on account of thanksgiving, along with the thank-offering sacrifice he must present unleavened loaves mixed with olive oil, unleavened wafers smeared with olive oil, and well-soaked, ring-shaped loaves made of choice wheat flour mixed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must present this grain offering in addition to ring-shaped loaves of leavened bread which regularly accompany the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must present one of each kind of grain offering as a contribution offering to the Lord; it belongs to the priest who splashes the blood of the peace offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The meat of his thanksgiving peace offering must be eaten on the day of his offering; he must not set any of it aside until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If his offering is a votive or freewill sacrifice, it may be eaten on the day he presents his sacrifice, and also the leftovers from it may be eaten on the next day,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the leftovers from the meat of the sacrifice must be burned up in the fire on the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: If some of the meat of his peace-offering sacrifice is ever eaten on the third day it will not be accepted; it will not be accounted to the one who presented it since it is spoiled, and the person who eats from it will bear his punishment for iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: The meat which touches anything ceremonially unclean must not be eaten; it must be burned up in the fire. As for ceremonially clean meat, everyone who is ceremonially clean may eat the meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who eats meat from the peace-offering sacrifice which belongs to the Lord while that person’s uncleanness persists will be cut off from his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a person touches anything unclean (whether human uncleanness, or an unclean animal, or an unclean detestable creature) and eats some of the meat of the peace-offering sacrifice which belongs to the Lord, that person will be cut off from his people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘You must not eat any fat of an ox, sheep, or goat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the fat of an animal that has died of natural causes and the fat of an animal torn by beasts may be used for any other purpose, but you must certainly never eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone eats fat from the animal from which he presents a gift to the Lord, that person will be cut off from his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must not eat any blood of the birds or of the domesticated land animals in any of the places where you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any person who eats any blood—that person will be cut off from his people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘The one who presents his peace-offering sacrifice to the Lord must bring part of his offering to the Lord as his sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his own hands he must bring the Lord’s gifts. He must bring the fat with the breast to wave the breast as a wave offering before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest must offer the fat up in smoke on the altar, but the breast will belong to Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The right thigh you must give as a contribution offering to the priest from your peace-offering sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one from Aaron’s sons who presents the blood of the peace offering and fat will have the right thigh as his share,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the contribution offering I have taken from the Israelites out of their peace-offering sacrifices and have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons from the people of Israel as a perpetual allotted portion.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the allotment of Aaron and the allotment of his sons from the Lord’s gifts on the day Moses presented them to serve as priests to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord commanded to give to them from the Israelites on the day Moses anointed them—a perpetual allotted portion throughout their generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law for the burnt offering, the grain offering, the sin offering, the guilt offering, the ordination offering, and the peace-offering sacrifice,
speaker: Narrator

text: which the Lord commanded Moses on Mount Sinai on the day he commanded the Israelites to present their offerings to the Lord in the desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take Aaron and his sons with him, and the garments, the anointing oil, the sin offering bull, the two rams, and the basket of unleavened bread,
speaker: Narrator

text: and assemble the whole congregation at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did just as the Lord commanded him, and the congregation assembled at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the congregation: “This is what the Lord has commanded to be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses brought Aaron and his sons forward and washed them with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he put the tunic on Aaron, wrapped the sash around him, and clothed him with the robe. Next he put the ephod on him and placed on him the decorated band of the ephod, and fastened the ephod closely to him with the band.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then set the breastpiece on him and put the Urim and Thummim into the breastpiece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, he set the turban on his head and attached the gold plate, the holy diadem, to the front of the turban just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took the anointing oil and anointed the tabernacle and everything in it, and so consecrated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he sprinkled some of it on the altar seven times and so anointed the altar, all its vessels, and the washbasin and its stand to consecrate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then poured some of the anointing oil on the head of Aaron and anointed him to consecrate him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also brought forward Aaron’s sons, clothed them with tunics, wrapped sashes around them, and wrapped headbands on them just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought near the sin offering bull and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the sin offering bull,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he slaughtered it. Moses then took the blood and put it all around on the horns of the altar with his finger and purified the altar, and he poured out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar and so consecrated it to make atonement on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took all the fat on the entrails, the protruding lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys and their fat, and Moses offered it all up in smoke on the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the rest of the bull—its hide, its flesh, and its dung—he completely burned up outside the camp just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he presented the burnt offering ram and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he slaughtered it. Moses then splashed the blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he cut the ram into parts, and Moses offered the head, the parts, and the suet up in smoke,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the entrails and the legs he washed with water, and Moses offered the whole ram up in smoke on the altar—it was a burnt offering for a soothing aroma, a gift to the Lord, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he presented the second ram, the ram of ordination, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram
speaker: Narrator

text: and he slaughtered it. Moses then took some of its blood and put it on Aaron’s right earlobe, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he brought Aaron’s sons forward, and Moses put some of the blood on their right earlobes, on their right thumbs, and on the big toes of their right feet, and Moses splashed the rest of the blood against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the fat (the fatty tail, all the fat on the entrails, the protruding lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys and their fat) and the right thigh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from the basket of unleavened bread that was before the Lord he took one unleavened loaf, one loaf of bread mixed with olive oil, and one wafer, and placed them on the fat parts and on the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then put all of them on the palms of Aaron and his sons, who waved them as a wave offering before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses then took them from their palms and offered them up in smoke on the altar on top of the burnt offering—they were an ordination offering for a soothing aroma; it was a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, Moses took the breast and waved it as a wave offering before the Lord from the ram of ordination. It was Moses’ share just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took some of the anointing oil and some of the blood which was on the altar and sprinkled it on Aaron and his garments, and on his sons and his sons’ garments. So he consecrated Aaron, his garments, and his sons and his sons’ garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron and his sons, “Boil the meat at the entrance of the Meeting Tent, and there you are to eat it and the bread which is in the ordination offering basket, just as I have commanded, saying, ‘Aaron and his sons are to eat it,’
speaker: Narrator

text: but the remainder of the meat and the bread you must burn with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must not go out from the entrance of the Meeting Tent for seven days, until the day when your days of ordination are completed, because you must be ordained over a seven-day period.
speaker: Narrator

text: What has been done on this day the Lord has commanded to be done to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must reside at the entrance of the Meeting Tent day and night for seven days and keep the charge of the Lord so that you will not die, for this is what I have been commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron and his sons did all the things the Lord had commanded through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day Moses summoned Aaron and his sons and the elders of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Aaron, “Take for yourself a bull calf for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, both flawless, and present them before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then tell the Israelites: ‘Take a male goat for a sin offering and a calf and a lamb, both a year old and flawless, for a burnt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: and an ox and a ram for peace offerings to sacrifice before the Lord, and a grain offering mixed with olive oil, for today the Lord is going to appear to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took what Moses had commanded to the front of the Meeting Tent and the whole congregation presented them and stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded you to do so that the glory of the Lord may appear to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses then said to Aaron, “Approach the altar and make your sin offering and your burnt offering, and make atonement on behalf of yourself and on behalf of the people; and also make the people’s offering and make atonement on behalf of them just as the Lord has commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron approached the altar and slaughtered the sin offering calf which was for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sons presented the blood to him and he dipped his finger in the blood and put it on the horns of the altar, and the rest of the blood he poured out at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fat and the kidneys and the protruding lobe of the liver from the sin offering he offered up in smoke on the altar just as the Lord had commanded Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the flesh and the hide he completely burned up outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then slaughtered the burnt offering, and his sons handed the blood to him and he splashed it against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: The burnt offering itself they handed to him by its parts, including the head, and he offered them up in smoke on the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he washed the entrails and the legs and offered them up in smoke on top of the burnt offering on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he presented the people’s offering. He took the sin offering male goat which was for the people, slaughtered it, and performed a purification rite with it like the first one.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then presented the burnt offering, and did it according to the standard regulation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he presented the grain offering, filled his hand with some of it, and offered it up in smoke on the altar in addition to the morning burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he slaughtered the ox and the ram—the peace-offering sacrifices which were for the people—and Aaron’s sons handed the blood to him and he splashed it against the altar’s sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the fat parts from the ox and from the ram (the fatty tail, the fat covering the entrails, the kidneys, and the protruding lobe of the liver),
speaker: Narrator

text: they set those on the breasts and he offered the fat parts up in smoke on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally Aaron waved the breasts and the right thigh as a wave offering before the Lord just as Moses had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron lifted up his hands toward the people and blessed them and descended from making the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the peace offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron then entered into the Meeting Tent. When they came out, they blessed the people, and the glory of the Lord appeared to all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fire went out from the presence of the Lord and consumed the burnt offering and the fat parts on the altar, and all the people saw it, so they shouted loudly and fell down with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sons, Nadab and Abihu, each took his fire pan and put fire in it, set incense on it, and presented strange fire before the Lord, which he had not commanded them to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So fire went out from the presence of the Lord and consumed them so that they died before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses then said to Aaron, “This is what the Lord spoke: ‘Among the ones close to me I will show myself holy, and in the presence of all the people I will be honored.’” So Aaron kept silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses then called to Mishael and Elzaphan, the sons of Uzziel, Aaron’s uncle, and said to them, “Come near, carry your brothers from the front of the sanctuary to a place outside the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came near and carried them away in their tunics to a place outside the camp just as Moses had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron and to Eleazar and Ithamar his other two sons, “Do not dishevel the hair of your heads and do not tear your garments, so that you do not die and so that wrath does not come on the whole congregation. Your brothers, all the house of Israel, are to mourn the burning that the Lord has caused,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you must not go out from the entrance of the Meeting Tent lest you die, for the Lord’s anointing oil is on you.” So they acted according to the word of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not drink wine or strong drink, you and your sons with you, when you enter into the Meeting Tent, so that you do not die. This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as to distinguish between the holy and the common, and between the unclean and the clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to teach the Israelites all the statutes that the Lord has spoken to them through Moses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses spoke to Aaron and to Eleazar and Ithamar, his remaining sons, “Take the grain offering which remains from the gifts of the Lord and eat it unleavened beside the altar, for it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must eat it in a holy place because it is your allotted portion and the allotted portion of your sons from the gifts of the Lord, for this is what I have been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the contribution offering you must eat in a ceremonially clean place, you and your sons and daughters with you, for the foods have been given as your allotted portion and the allotted portion of your sons from the peace-offering sacrifices of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thigh of the contribution offering and the breast of the wave offering they must bring in addition to the gifts of the fat parts to wave them as a wave offering before the Lord, and it will belong to you and your sons with you for a perpetual statute just as the Lord has commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later Moses sought diligently for the sin offering male goat, but it had actually been burnt. So he became angry at Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s remaining sons, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why did you not eat the sin offering in the sanctuary? For it is most holy and he gave it to you to bear the iniquity of the congregation, to make atonement on their behalf before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: See here! Its blood was not brought into the Holy Place within! You should certainly have eaten it in the sanctuary just as I commanded!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Aaron spoke to Moses, “See here! Just today they presented their sin offering and their burnt offering before the Lord and such things as these have happened to me! If I had eaten a sin offering today would the Lord have been pleased?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this explanation, he was satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: ‘This is the kind of creature you may eat from among all the animals that are on the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat any among the animals that has a divided hoof (the hooves are completely split in two) and that also chews the cud.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you must not eat these from among those that chew the cud and have divided hooves: The camel is unclean to you because it chews the cud even though its hoof is not divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rock badger is unclean to you because it chews the cud even though its hoof is not divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hare is unclean to you because it chews the cud even though its hoof is not divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pig is unclean to you because its hoof is divided (the hoof is completely split in two) , even though it does not chew the cud.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat from their meat and you must not touch their carcasses; they are unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘These you can eat from all creatures that are in the water: Any creatures in the water that have both fins and scales, whether in the seas or in the streams, you may eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any creatures that do not have both fins and scales, whether in the seas or in the streams, from all the swarming things of the water and from all the living creatures that are in the water, are detestable to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since they are detestable to you, you must not eat their meat and their carcass you must detest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any creature in the water that does not have both fins and scales is detestable to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘These you are to detest from among the birds—they must not be eaten, because they are detestable: the griffon vulture, the bearded vulture, the black vulture,
speaker: Narrator

text: the kite, the buzzard of any kind,
speaker: Narrator

text: every kind of crow,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eagle owl, the short-eared owl, the long-eared owl, the hawk of any kind,
speaker: Narrator

text: the little owl, the cormorant, the screech owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: the white owl, the scops owl, the osprey,
speaker: Narrator

text: the stork, the heron of any kind, the hoopoe, and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Every winged swarming thing that walks on all fours is detestable to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, this you may eat from all the winged swarming things that walk on all fours, which have jointed legs to hop with on the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: These you may eat from them: the locust of any kind, the bald locust of any kind, the cricket of any kind, the grasshopper of any kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any other winged swarming thing that has four legs is detestable to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘By these you defile yourselves—anyone who touches their carcass will be unclean until the evening,
speaker: Narrator

text: and anyone who carries their carcass must wash his clothes and will be unclean until the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘All animals that divide the hoof, but it is not completely split in two, and do not chew the cud are unclean to you; anyone who touches them becomes unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that walk on their paws among all the creatures that walk on all fours are unclean to you. Anyone who touches their carcass will be unclean until the evening,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the one who carries their carcass must wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening; they are unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now this is what is unclean to you among the swarming things that swarm on the land: the rat, the mouse, the large lizard of any kind,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Mediterranean gecko, the spotted lizard, the wall gecko, the skink, and the chameleon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the ones that are unclean to you among all the swarming things. Anyone who touches these creatures when they die will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, anything they fall on when they die will become unclean—any wood vessel or garment or article of leather or sackcloth. Any such vessel with which work is done must be immersed in water and will be unclean until the evening. Then it will become clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for any clay vessel they fall into, everything in it will become unclean and you must break it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any food that may be eaten which becomes soaked with water will become unclean. Anything drinkable in any such vessel will become unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything their carcass may fall on will become unclean. An oven or small stove must be smashed to pieces; they are unclean, and they will stay unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, a spring or a cistern which collects water will be clean, but one who touches the creature’s carcass will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, if such a carcass falls on any sowing seed which is to be sown, it is clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if water is put on the seed and such a carcass falls on it, it is unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Now if an animal that you may eat dies, whoever touches its carcass will be unclean until the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: One who eats from its carcass must wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening, and whoever carries its carcass must wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every swarming thing that swarms on the land is detestable; it must not be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat anything that crawls on its belly or anything that walks on all fours or on any number of legs of all the swarming things that swarm on the land, because they are detestable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not make yourselves detestable by any of the swarming things. You must not defile yourselves by them and become unclean by them,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I am the Lord your God and you are to sanctify yourselves and be holy because I am holy. You must not defile yourselves by any of the swarming things that creep on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I am the Lord who brought you up from the land of Egypt to be your God, and you are to be holy because I am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law of the land animals, the birds, all the living creatures that move in the water, and all the creatures that swarm on the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: to distinguish between the unclean and the clean, between the living creatures that may be eaten and the living creatures that must not be eaten.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘When a woman produces offspring and bears a male child, she will be unclean seven days, as she is unclean during the days of her menstruation.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin must be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she will remain thirty-three days in blood purity. She must not touch anything holy and she must not enter the sanctuary until the days of her purification are fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she bears a female child, she will be impure fourteen days as during her menstrual flow, and she will remain sixty-six days in blood purity.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When the days of her purification are completed for a son or for a daughter, she must bring a one-year-old lamb for a burnt offering and a young pigeon or turtledove for a sin offering to the entrance of the Meeting Tent, to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to present it before the Lord and make atonement on her behalf, and she will be clean from her flow of blood. This is the law of the one who bears a child, for the male or the female child.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she cannot afford a sheep, then she must take two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a burnt offering and one for a sin offering, and the priest is to make atonement on her behalf, and she will be clean.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone has a swelling or a scab or a bright spot on the skin of his body that may become a diseased infection, he must be brought to Aaron the priest or one of his sons, the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine the infection on the skin of the body, and if the hair in the infection has turned white and the infection appears to be deeper than the skin of the body, then it is a diseased infection, so when the priest examines it he must pronounce the person unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If it is a white bright spot on the skin of his body, but it does not appear to be deeper than the skin, and the hair has not turned white, then the priest is to quarantine the person with the infection for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine it on the seventh day, and if, as far as he can see, the infection has stayed the same and has not spread on the skin, then the priest is to quarantine the person for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine it again on the seventh day, and if the infection has faded and has not spread on the skin, then the priest is to pronounce the person clean. It is a scab, so he must wash his clothes and be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the scab is spreading further on the skin after he has shown himself to the priest for his purification, then he must show himself to the priest a second time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine it, and if the scab has spread on the skin, then the priest is to pronounce the person unclean. It is a disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone has a diseased infection, he must be brought to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then examine it, and if a white swelling is on the skin, it has turned the hair white, and there is raw flesh in the swelling,
speaker: Narrator

text: it is a chronic disease on the skin of his body, so the priest is to pronounce him unclean. The priest must not merely quarantine him, for he is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the disease breaks out on the skin so that the disease covers all the skin of the person with the infection from his head to his feet, as far as the priest can see,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest must then examine it, and if the disease covers his whole body, he is to pronounce the person with the infection clean. He has turned all white, so he is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever raw flesh appears in it he will be unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the priest is to examine the raw flesh and pronounce him unclean—it is diseased.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the raw flesh once again turns white, then he must come to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then examine it, and if the infection has turned white, the priest is to pronounce the person with the infection clean—he is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone’s body has a boil on its skin and it heals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the place of the boil there is a white swelling or a reddish white bright spot, he must show himself to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then examine it, and if it appears to be deeper than the skin and its hair has turned white, then the priest is to pronounce the person unclean. It is a diseased infection that has broken out in the boil.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the priest examines it, and there is no white hair in it, it is not deeper than the skin, and it has faded, then the priest is to quarantine him for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is spreading farther on the skin, then the priest is to pronounce him unclean. It is an infection.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the bright spot stays in its place and has not spread, it is the scar of the boil, so the priest is to pronounce him clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a body has a burn on its skin and the raw area of the burn becomes a reddish white or white bright spot,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest must examine it, and if the hair has turned white in the bright spot and it appears to be deeper than the skin, it is a disease that has broken out in the burn. The priest is to pronounce the person unclean. It is a diseased infection.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the priest examines it and there is no white hair in the bright spot, it is not deeper than the skin, and it has faded, then the priest is to quarantine him for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine it on the seventh day, and if it is spreading further on the skin, then the priest is to pronounce him unclean. It is a diseased infection.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the bright spot stays in its place, has not spread on the skin, and it has faded, then it is the swelling of the burn, so the priest is to pronounce him clean, because it is the scar of the burn.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man or a woman has an infection on the head or in the beard,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine the infection, and if it appears to be deeper than the skin and the hair in it is reddish yellow and thin, then the priest is to pronounce the person unclean. It is scall, a disease of the head or the beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines the scall infection and it does not appear to be deeper than the skin, and there is no black hair in it, then the priest is to quarantine the person with the scall infection for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine the infection on the seventh day, and if the scall has not spread, there is no reddish yellow hair in it, and the scall does not appear to be deeper than the skin,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the individual is to shave himself, but he must not shave the area affected by the scall, and the priest is to quarantine the person with the scall for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine the scall on the seventh day, and if the scall has not spread on the skin and it does not appear to be deeper than the skin, then the priest is to pronounce him clean. So he is to wash his clothes and be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the scall spreads further on the skin after his purification,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the priest is to examine it, and if the scall has spread on the skin the priest is not to search further for reddish yellow hair. The person is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, as far as the priest can see, the scall has stayed the same and black hair has sprouted in it, the scall has been healed; the person is clean. So the priest is to pronounce him clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man or a woman has bright spots—white bright spots—on the skin of their body,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine them, and if the bright spots on the skin of their body are faded white, it is a harmless rash that has broken out on the skin. The person is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man’s head is bare so that he is balding in back, he is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his head is bare on the forehead so that he is balding in front, he is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is a reddish white infection in the back or front bald area, it is a disease breaking out in his back or front bald area.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine it, and if the swelling of the infection is reddish white in the back or the front bald area like the appearance of a disease on the skin of the body,
speaker: Narrator

text: he is a diseased man. He is unclean. The priest must surely pronounce him unclean because of his infection on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for the diseased person who has the infection, his clothes must be torn, the hair of his head must be unbound, he must cover his mustache, and he must call out ‘Unclean! Unclean!’
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole time he has the infection he will be continually unclean. He must live in isolation, and his place of residence must be outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a garment has a diseased infection in it, whether a wool or linen garment,
speaker: Narrator

text: or in the warp or woof of the linen or the wool, or in leather or anything made of leather,
speaker: Narrator

text: if the infection in the garment or leather or warp or woof or any article of leather is yellowish green or reddish, it is a diseased infection and it must be shown to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine and then quarantine the article with the infection for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must then examine the infection on the seventh day. If the infection has spread in the garment, or in the warp, or in the woof, or in the leather—whatever the article into which the leather was made—the infection is a malignant disease. It is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must burn the garment or the warp or the woof, whether wool or linen, or any article of leather which has the infection in it. Because it is a malignant disease it must be burned up in the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines it and the infection has not spread in the garment or in the warp or in the woof or in any article of leather,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to command that they wash whatever has the infection and quarantine it for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then examine it after the infection has been washed out, and if the infection has not changed its appearance even though the infection has not spread, it is unclean. You must burn it up in the fire. It is a fungus, whether on the back side or front side of the article.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest has examined it and the infection has faded after it has been washed, he is to tear it out of the garment or the leather or the warp or the woof.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then if it still appears again in the garment or the warp or the woof, or in any article of leather, it is an outbreak. Whatever has the infection in it you must burn up in the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the garment or the warp or the woof or any article of leather which you wash and infection disappears from it is to be washed a second time and it will be clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law of the diseased infection in the garment of wool or linen, or the warp or woof, or any article of leather, for pronouncing it clean or unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the law of the diseased person on the day of his purification, when he is brought to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to go outside the camp and examine the infection. If the infection of the diseased person has been healed,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the priest will command that two live clean birds, a piece of cedar wood, a scrap of crimson fabric, and some twigs of hyssop be taken up for the one being cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then command that one bird be slaughtered into a clay vessel over fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take the live bird along with the piece of cedar wood, the scrap of crimson fabric, and the twigs of hyssop, and he is to dip them and the live bird in the blood of the bird slaughtered over the fresh water,
speaker: Narrator

text: and sprinkle it seven times on the one being cleansed from the disease, pronounce him clean, and send the live bird away over the open countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The one being cleansed must then wash his clothes, shave off all his hair, and bathe in water, and so be clean. Then afterward he may enter the camp, but he must live outside his tent seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the seventh day comes he must shave all his hair—his head, his beard, his eyebrows, all his hair—and he must wash his clothes, bathe his body in water, and so be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the eighth day he must take two flawless male lambs, one flawless yearling female lamb, three-tenths of an ephah of choice wheat flour as a grain offering mixed with olive oil, and one log of olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest who pronounces him clean will have the man who is being cleansed stand along with these offerings before the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest is to take one male lamb and present it for a guilt offering along with the log of olive oil and present them as a wave offering before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must then slaughter the male lamb in the place where the sin offering and the burnt offering are slaughtered, in the sanctuary, because, like the sin offering, the guilt offering belongs to the priest; it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest is to take some of the blood of the guilt offering and put it on the right earlobe of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then take some of the log of olive oil and pour it into his own left hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest is to dip his right forefinger into the olive oil that is in his left hand, and sprinkle some of the olive oil with his finger seven times before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then put some of the rest of the olive oil that is in his hand on the right earlobe of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot, on the blood of the guilt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the remainder of the olive oil that is in his hand the priest is to put on the head of the one being cleansed. So the priest is to make atonement for him before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest must then perform the sin offering and make atonement for the one being cleansed from his impurity. After that he is to slaughter the burnt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to offer the burnt offering and the grain offering on the altar. So the priest is to make atonement for him and he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the person is poor and does not have sufficient means, he must take one male lamb as a guilt offering for a wave offering to make atonement for himself, one-tenth of an ephah of choice wheat flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering, a log of olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two turtledoves or two young pigeons, which are within his means. One will be a sin offering and the other a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the eighth day he must bring them for his purification to the priest at the entrance of the Meeting Tent before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to take the male lamb of the guilt offering and the log of olive oil and wave them as a wave offering before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to slaughter the male lamb of the guilt offering, and the priest is to take some of the blood of the guilt offering and put it on the right earlobe of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then pour some of the olive oil into his own left hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and sprinkle some of the olive oil that is in his left hand with his right forefinger seven times before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest is to put some of the olive oil that is in his hand on the right earlobe of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot, on the place of the blood of the guilt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the remainder of the olive oil that is in the hand of the priest he is to put on the head of the one being cleansed to make atonement for him before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He will then make one of the turtledoves or young pigeons, which are within his means,
speaker: Narrator

text: a sin offering and the other a burnt offering along with the grain offering. So the priest is to make atonement for the one being cleansed before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law of the one in whom there is a diseased infection, who does not have sufficient means for his purification.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter the land of Canaan which I am about to give to you for a possession, and I put a diseased infection in a house in the land you are to possess,
speaker: Narrator

text: then whoever owns the house must come and declare to the priest, ‘Something like an infection is visible to me in the house.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will command that the house be cleared before the priest enters to examine the infection so that everything in the house does not become unclean, and afterward the priest will enter to examine the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to examine the infection, and if the infection in the walls of the house consists of yellowish green or reddish eruptions, and it appears to be deeper than the surface of the wall,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the priest is to go out of the house to the doorway of the house and quarantine the house for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must return on the seventh day and examine it, and if the infection has spread in the walls of the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the priest is to command that the stones that had the infection in them be pulled and thrown outside the city into an unclean place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they shall scrape the house all around on the inside, and the plaster which they have scraped off must be dumped outside the city into an unclean place.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are then to take other stones and replace those stones, and he is to take other plaster and replaster the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the infection returns and breaks out in the house after he has pulled out the stones, scraped the house, and it is replastered,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to come and examine it, and if the infection has spread in the house, it is a malignant disease in the house. It is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must tear down the house, its stones, its wood, and all the plaster of the house, and bring all of it outside the city to an unclean place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who enters the house all the days the priest has quarantined it will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who lies down in the house must wash his clothes. Anyone who eats in the house must wash his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If, however, the priest enters and examines it, and the infection has not spread in the house after the house has been replastered, then the priest is to pronounce the house clean because the infection has been healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take two birds, a piece of cedar wood, a scrap of crimson fabric, and some twigs of hyssop to purify the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he is to slaughter one bird into a clay vessel over fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must then take the piece of cedar wood, the twigs of hyssop, the scrap of crimson fabric, and the live bird, and dip them in the blood of the slaughtered bird and in the fresh water, and sprinkle the house seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he is to purify the house with the blood of the bird, the fresh water, the live bird, the piece of cedar wood, the twigs of hyssop, and the scrap of crimson fabric,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he is to send the live bird away outside the city into the open countryside. So he is to make atonement for the house and it will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the law for all diseased infections, for scall,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the diseased garment, for the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the swelling, for the scab, and for the bright spot,
speaker: Narrator

text: to teach when something is unclean and when it is clean. This is the law for dealing with infectious disease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When any man has a discharge from his body, his discharge is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is his uncleanness in regard to his discharge—whether his body secretes his discharge or blocks his discharge, he is unclean. All the days that his body has a discharge or his body blocks his discharge, this is his uncleanness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Any bed the man with a discharge lies on will be unclean, and any furniture he sits on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches his bed must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who sits on the furniture the man with a discharge sits on must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who touches the body of the man with a discharge must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the man with a discharge spits on a person who is ceremonially clean, that person must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any means of riding that the man with a discharge rides on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches anything that was under him will be unclean until evening, and the one who carries those items must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone whom the man with the discharge touches without having rinsed his hands in water must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: A clay vessel which the man with the discharge touches must be broken, and any wooden utensil must be rinsed in water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When the man with the discharge becomes clean from his discharge he is to count off for himself seven days for his purification, and he must wash his clothes, bathe in fresh water, and be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the eighth day he is to take for himself two turtledoves or two young pigeons, and he is to present himself before the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent and give them to the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to make one of them a sin offering and the other a burnt offering. So the priest is to make atonement for him before the Lord for his discharge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a man has a seminal emission, he must bathe his whole body in water and be unclean until evening,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he must wash in water any clothing or leather that has semen on it, and it will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for a woman whom a man goes to bed with, then has a seminal emission, they must bathe in water and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a woman has a discharge and her discharge is blood from her body, she is to be in her menstruation seven days, and anyone who touches her will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything she lies on during her menstruation will be unclean, and anything she sits on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches her bed must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches any furniture she sits on must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is something on the bed or on the furniture she sits on, when he touches it he will be unclean until evening,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if a man actually goes to bed with her so that her menstrual impurity touches him, then he will be unclean seven days and any bed he lies on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a woman’s discharge of blood flows many days not at the time of her menstruation, or if it flows beyond the time of her menstruation, all the days of her discharge of impurity will be like the days of her menstruation—she is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any bed she lies on all the days of her discharge will be to her like the bed of her menstruation, any furniture she sits on will be unclean like the impurity of her menstruation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and anyone who touches them will be unclean, and he must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If she becomes clean from her discharge, then she is to count off for herself seven days, and afterward she will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the eighth day she must take for herself two turtledoves or two young pigeons and she must bring them to the priest at the entrance of the Meeting Tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to make one a sin offering and the other a burnt offering. So the priest is to make atonement for her before the Lord from her discharge of impurity.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Thus you are to set the Israelites apart from their impurity so that they do not die in their impurity by defiling my tabernacle which is in their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the law for the one with a discharge: for the one who has a seminal emission and becomes unclean by it,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the one who is sick in her menstruation, for the one with a discharge, whether male or female, and for a man who goes to bed with an unclean woman.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses after the death of Aaron’s two sons when they approached the presence of the Lord and died,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord said to Moses: “Tell Aaron your brother that he must not enter at any time into the Holy Place inside the special curtain in front of the atonement lid that is on the ark so that he may not die, for I will appear in the cloud over the atonement lid.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In this way Aaron is to enter into the sanctuary—with a young bull for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must put on a holy linen tunic, linen leggings are to cover his body, and he is to wrap himself with a linen sash and wrap his head with a linen turban. They are holy garments, so he must bathe his body in water and put them on.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must also take two male goats from the congregation of the Israelites for a sin offering and one ram for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron is to present the sin offering bull which is for himself and is to make atonement on behalf of himself and his household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he must take the two goats and stand them before the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent,
speaker: Narrator
