text: and Aaron is to cast lots over the two goats, one lot for the Lord and one lot for Azazel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron must then present the goat which has been designated by lot for the Lord, and he is to make it a sin offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the goat which has been designated by lot for Azazel is to be stood alive before the Lord to make atonement on it by sending it away into the desert to Azazel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron is to present the sin-offering bull which is for himself, and he is to make atonement on behalf of himself and his household. He is to slaughter the sin-offering bull which is for himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: and take a censer full of coals of fire from the altar before the Lord and a full double handful of finely ground fragrant incense, and bring them inside the curtain.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must then put the incense on the fire before the Lord, and the cloud of incense will cover the atonement lid which is above the ark of the testimony, so that he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take some of the blood of the bull and sprinkle it with his finger on the eastern face of the atonement lid, and in front of the atonement lid he is to sprinkle some of the blood seven times with his finger.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron must then slaughter the sin-offering goat which is for the people. He is to bring its blood inside the curtain, and he is to do with its blood just as he did to the blood of the bull: He is to sprinkle it on the atonement lid and in front of the atonement lid.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he is to make atonement for the Holy Place from the impurities of the Israelites and from their transgressions with regard to all their sins, and thus he is to do for the Meeting Tent which resides with them in the midst of their impurities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nobody is to be in the Meeting Tent when he enters to make atonement in the Holy Place until he goes out, and he has made atonement on his behalf, on behalf of his household, and on behalf of the whole assembly of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then Aaron is to go out to the altar which is before the Lord and make atonement for it. He is to take some of the blood of the bull and some of the blood of the goat, and put it all around on the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to sprinkle on it some of the blood with his finger seven times, and cleanse and consecrate it from the impurities of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Aaron has finished purifying the Holy Place, the Meeting Tent, and the altar, he is to present the live goat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron is to lay his two hands on the head of the live goat and confess over it all the iniquities of the Israelites and all their transgressions in regard to all their sins, and thus he is to put them on the head of the goat and send it away into the desert by the hand of a man standing ready.
speaker: Narrator

text: The goat is to bear on itself all their iniquities into an inaccessible land, so he is to send the goat away into the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron must then enter the Meeting Tent and take off the linen garments which he had put on when he entered the sanctuary, and leave them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must bathe his body in water in the Holy Place, put on his clothes, and go out and make his burnt offering and the people’s burnt offering. So he is to make atonement on behalf of himself and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he is to offer up the fat of the sin offering in smoke on the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the one who sent the goat away to Azazel must wash his clothes, bathe his body in water, and afterward he may reenter the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought to make atonement in the Holy Place, must be brought outside the camp and their hide, their flesh, and their dung must be burned up,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the one who burns them must wash his clothes and bathe his body in water, and afterward he may reenter the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is to be a perpetual statute for you. In the seventh month, on the tenth day of the month, you must humble yourselves and do no work of any kind, both the native citizen and the resident foreigner who lives in your midst,
speaker: Narrator

text: for on this day atonement is to be made for you to cleanse you from all your sins; you must be clean before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to be a Sabbath of complete rest for you, and you must humble yourselves. It is a perpetual statute.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest who is anointed and ordained to act as high priest in place of his father is to make atonement. He is to put on the linen garments, the holy garments,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he is to purify the Most Holy Place, he is to purify the Meeting Tent and the altar, and he is to make atonement for the priests and for all the people of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is to be a perpetual statute for you to make atonement for the Israelites for all their sins once a year.” So he did just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelites, and tell them, ‘This is the word that the Lord has commanded,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blood guilt will be accounted to any man from the house of Israel who slaughters an ox or a lamb or a goat inside the camp or outside the camp,
speaker: Narrator

text: but has not brought it to the entrance of the Meeting Tent to present it as an offering to the Lord before the tabernacle of the Lord. He has shed blood, so that man will be cut off from the midst of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is so that the Israelites will bring their sacrifices that they are sacrificing in the open field to the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent—to the priest—and sacrifice them there as peace-offering sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to splash the blood on the altar of the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent, and offer the fat up in smoke for a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people must no longer offer their sacrifices to the goat demons, acting like prostitutes by going after them. This is to be a perpetual statute for them throughout their generations.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to say to them: ‘Any man from the house of Israel or from the resident foreigners who live in their midst, who offers a burnt offering or a sacrifice
speaker: Narrator

text: but does not bring it to the entrance of the Meeting Tent to offer it to the Lord—that person will be cut off from his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Any man from the house of Israel or from the resident foreigners who live in their midst who eats any blood, I will set my face against that person who eats the blood, and I will cut him off from the midst of his people,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the life of every living thing is in the blood. So I myself have assigned it to you on the altar to make atonement for your lives, for the blood makes atonement by means of the life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, I have said to the Israelites: No person among you is to eat blood, and no resident foreigner who lives among you is to eat blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Any man from the Israelites or from the resident foreigners who live in their midst who hunts a wild animal or a bird that may be eaten must pour out its blood and cover it with soil,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the life of all flesh is its blood. So I have said to the Israelites: You must not eat the blood of any living thing because the life of every living thing is its blood—all who eat it will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Any person who eats an animal that has died of natural causes or an animal torn by beasts, whether a native citizen or a resident foreigner, must wash his clothes, bathe in water, and be unclean until evening; then he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he does not wash his clothes and does not bathe his body, he will bear his punishment for his iniquity.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘I am the Lord your God!
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do as they do in the land of Egypt where you have been living, and you must not do as they do in the land of Canaan into which I am about to bring you; you must not walk in their statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must observe my regulations and you must be sure to walk in my statutes. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must keep my statutes and my regulations; anyone who does so will live by keeping them. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘No man is to approach any close relative to have sexual relations with her. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not expose your father’s nakedness by having sexual relations with your mother. She is your mother; you must not have sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your father’s wife; she is your father’s nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your sister, whether she is your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter, whether she is born in the same household or born outside it; you must not have sexual relations with either of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not expose the nakedness of your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter by having sexual relations with them, because they are your own nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with the daughter of your father’s wife born of your father; she is your sister. You must not have sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your father’s sister; she is your father’s flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your mother’s sister, because she is your mother’s flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not expose the nakedness of your father’s brother; you must not approach his wife to have marital relations with her. She is your aunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law; she is your son’s wife. You must not have sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with your brother’s wife; she is your brother’s nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with both a woman and her daughter; you must not take as wife either her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter to have sexual relations with them. They are closely related to her—it is lewdness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not take a woman in marriage and then marry her sister as a rival wife while she is still alive, to have sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not approach a woman in her menstrual impurity to have sexual relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with the wife of your fellow citizen to become unclean with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not give any of your children as an offering to Molech, so that you do not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with a male as one has sexual relations with a woman; it is a detestable act.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not have sexual relations with any animal to become defiled with it, and a woman must not stand before an animal to have sexual relations with it; it is a perversion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Do not defile yourselves with any of these things, for the nations that I am about to drive out before you have been defiled with all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the land has become unclean and I have brought the punishment for its iniquity upon it, so that the land has vomited out its inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves must obey my statutes and my regulations and must not do any of these abominations, both the native citizen and the resident foreigner in your midst,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the people who were in the land before you have done all these abominations, and the land has become unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do not make the land vomit you out because you defile it just as it has vomited out the nations that were before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone does any of these abominations, that person who does them will be cut off from the midst of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must obey my charge not to practice any of the abominable statutes that have been done before you, so that you do not defile yourselves by them. I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the whole congregation of the Israelites and tell them, ‘You must be holy because I, the Lord your God, am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of you must respect his mother and his father, and you must keep my Sabbaths. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not turn to idols, and you must not make for yourselves gods of cast metal. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you sacrifice a peace-offering sacrifice to the Lord, you must sacrifice it so that it is accepted for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be eaten on the day of your sacrifice and on the following day, but what is left over until the third day must be burned up.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, it is eaten on the third day, it is spoiled; it will not be accepted,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the one who eats it will bear his punishment for iniquity because he has profaned what is holy to the Lord. That person will be cut off from his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you gather in the harvest of your land, you must not completely harvest the corner of your field, and you must not gather up the gleanings of your harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not pick your vineyard bare, and you must not gather up the fallen grapes of your vineyard. You must leave them for the poor and the resident foreigner. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not steal, you must not tell lies, and you must not deal falsely with your fellow citizen.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not swear falsely in my name, so that you do not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not oppress your neighbor or commit robbery against your neighbor. You must not withhold the wages of the hired laborer overnight until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not curse a deaf person or put a stumbling block in front of a blind person. You must fear your God; I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not deal unjustly in judgment: You must neither show partiality to the poor nor honor the rich. You must judge your fellow citizen fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not go about as a slanderer among your people. You must not stand idly by when your neighbor’s life is at stake. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not hate your brother in your heart. You must surely reprove your fellow citizen so that you do not incur sin on account of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not take vengeance or bear a grudge against any of your people, but you must love your neighbor as yourself. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must keep my statutes. You must not allow two different kinds of your animals to breed together, you must not sow your field with two different kinds of seed, and you must not wear a garment made of two different kinds of material.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When a man goes to bed with a woman for intercourse, although she is a slave woman designated for another man and she has not yet been ransomed, or freedom has not been granted to her, there will be an obligation to pay compensation. They must not be put to death, because she was not free.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring his guilt offering to the Lord at the entrance of the Meeting Tent, a guilt offering ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering before the Lord for his sin that he has committed, and he will be forgiven of his sin that he has committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you enter the land and plant any fruit tree, you must consider its fruit to be forbidden. Three years it will be forbidden to you; it must not be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year all its fruit will be holy, praise offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in the fifth year you may eat its fruit to add its produce to your harvest. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not eat anything with the blood still in it. You must not practice either divination or soothsaying.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not round off the corners of the hair on your head or ruin the corners of your beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not slash your body for a dead person or incise a tattoo on yourself. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not profane your daughter by making her a prostitute, so that the land does not practice prostitution and become full of lewdness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must keep my Sabbaths and fear my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not turn to the spirits of the dead and do not seek familiar spirits to become unclean by them. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must stand up in the presence of the aged, honor the presence of an elder, and fear your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a resident foreigner lives with you in your land, you must not oppress him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The resident foreigner who lives with you must be to you as a native citizen among you; so you must love the foreigner as yourself, because you were foreigners in the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do injustice in the regulation of measures, whether of length, weight, or volume.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have honest balances, honest weights, an honest ephah, and an honest hin. I am the Lord your God who brought you out from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be sure to obey all my statutes and regulations. I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to say to the Israelites, ‘Any man from the Israelites (or any of the resident foreigners who live in Israel) who gives any of his children to Molech must be put to death; the people of the land must pelt him with stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will set my face against that man and cut him off from the midst of his people, because he has given some of his children to Molech and thereby defiled my sanctuary and profaned my holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the people of the land shut their eyes to that man when he gives some of his children to Molech so that they do not put him to death,
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will set my face against that man and his clan. I will cut off from the midst of the people both him and all who follow after him in spiritual prostitution, committing prostitution by worshiping Molech.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The person who turns to the spirits of the dead and familiar spirits to commit prostitution by going after them, I will set my face against that person and cut him off from the midst of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must sanctify yourselves and be holy, because I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be sure to obey my statutes. I am the Lord who sanctifies you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If anyone curses his father or mother he must be put to death. He has cursed his father or mother; his blood guilt is on himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man commits adultery with his neighbor’s wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man goes to bed with his father’s wife, he has exposed his father’s nakedness. Both of them must be put to death; their blood guilt is on themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man goes to bed with his daughter-in-law, both of them must be put to death. They have committed perversion; their blood guilt is on themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man goes to bed with a male as one goes to bed with a woman, the two of them have committed an abomination. They must be put to death; their blood guilt is on themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has marital relations with both a woman and her mother, it is lewdness. Both he and they must be burned to death, so there is no lewdness in your midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has sexual relations with any animal, he must be put to death, and you must kill the animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a woman approaches any animal to copulate with it, you must kill the woman, and the animal must be put to death; their blood guilt is on themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man has marital relations with his sister, whether the daughter of his father or of his mother, so that he sees her nakedness and she sees his nakedness, it is a disgrace. They must be cut off in the sight of the children of their people. He has exposed his sister’s nakedness; he will bear his punishment for iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man goes to bed with a menstruating woman and uncovers her nakedness, he has laid bare her fountain of blood and she has exposed the fountain of her blood, so both of them must be cut off from the midst of their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not expose the nakedness of your mother’s sister or your father’s sister, for such a person has exposed his own close relative. They must bear their punishment for iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man goes to bed with his aunt, he has exposed his uncle’s nakedness; they must bear responsibility for their sin, they will die childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has marital relations with his brother’s wife, it is indecency. He has exposed his brother’s nakedness; they will be childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must be sure to obey all my statutes and regulations, so that the land to which I am about to bring you to take up residence does not vomit you out.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not walk in the statutes of the nations which I am about to drive out before you, because they have done all these things and I am filled with disgust against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have said to you: You yourselves will possess their land and I myself will give it to you for a possession, a land flowing with milk and honey. I am the Lord your God who has set you apart from the other peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you must distinguish between the clean animal and the unclean, and between the unclean bird and the clean, and you must not make yourselves detestable by means of an animal or bird or anything that creeps on the ground—creatures I have distinguished for you as unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be holy to me because I, the Lord, am holy, and I have set you apart from the other peoples to be mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘A man or woman who has in them a spirit of the dead or a familiar spirit must be put to death. They must pelt them with stones; their blood guilt is on themselves.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Say to the priests, the sons of Aaron—say to them: ‘For a dead person no priest is to defile himself among his people,
speaker: Narrator

text: except for his close relative who is near to him—his mother, his father, his son, his daughter, his brother,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his virgin sister who is near to him, who has no husband—he may defile himself for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not defile himself as a husband among his people so as to profane himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Priests must not have a bald spot shaved on their head, they must not shave the corner of their beard, and they must not cut slashes in their body.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘They must be holy to their God, and they must not profane the name of their God, because they are the ones who present the Lord’s gifts, the food of their God. Therefore they must be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not take a wife defiled by prostitution, nor are they to take a wife divorced from her husband, for the priest is holy to his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must sanctify him because he presents the food of your God. He must be holy to you because I, the Lord who sanctifies you all, am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a daughter of a priest profanes herself by engaging in prostitution, she is profaning her father. She must be burned to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The high priest—who is greater than his brothers, and on whose head the anointing oil is poured, and who has been ordained to wear the priestly garments—must neither dishevel the hair of his head nor tear his garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not go where there is any dead person; he must not defile himself even for his father or for his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not go out from the sanctuary and must not profane the sanctuary of his God, because the dedication of the anointing oil of his God is on him. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must take a wife who is a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not marry a widow, a divorced woman, or one profaned by prostitution; he may only take a virgin from his people as a wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he does not profane his children among his people, for I am the Lord who sanctifies him.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron, ‘No man from your descendants throughout their generations who has a physical flaw is to approach to present the food of his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly no man who has a physical flaw is to approach: a blind man, or one who is lame, or one with a slit nose, or who has a limb too long,
speaker: Narrator

text: or a man who has had a broken leg or arm,
speaker: Narrator

text: or a hunchback, or a dwarf, or one with a spot in his eye, or a festering eruption, or a feverish rash, or a crushed testicle.
speaker: Narrator

text: No man from the descendants of Aaron the priest who has a physical flaw may step forward to present the Lord’s gifts; he has a physical flaw, so he must not step forward to present the food of his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may eat both the most holy and the holy food of his God,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he must not go near the special curtain or step forward to the altar because he has a physical flaw. Thus he must not profane my holy places, for I am the Lord who sanctifies them.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke these things to Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons that they must deal respectfully with the holy offerings of the Israelites, which they consecrate to me, so that they do not profane my holy name. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘Throughout your generations, if any man from all your descendants approaches the holy offerings, which the Israelites consecrate to the Lord, while he is impure, that person must be cut off from before me. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: No man from the descendants of Aaron who is diseased or has a discharge may eat the holy offerings until he becomes clean. The one who touches anything made unclean by contact with a dead person, or with a man who has a seminal emission,
speaker: Narrator

text: or with a man who touches a swarming thing by which he becomes unclean, or who touches a person by which he becomes unclean, whatever that person’s impurity—
speaker: Narrator

text: the person who touches any of these will be unclean until evening and must not eat from the holy offerings unless he has bathed his body in water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun goes down he will be clean, and afterward he may eat from the holy offerings, because they are his food.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not eat an animal that has died of natural causes or an animal torn by beasts and thus become unclean by it. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must keep my charge so that they do not incur sin on account of it and therefore die because they profane it. I am the Lord who sanctifies them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘No lay person may eat anything holy. Neither a priest’s lodger nor a hired laborer may eat anything holy,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if a priest buys a person with his own money, that person may eat the holy offerings, and those born in the priest’s own house may eat his food.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a priest’s daughter marries a lay person, she may not eat the holy contribution offerings,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if a priest’s daughter is a widow or divorced, and she has no children so that she returns to live in her father’s house as in her youth, she may eat from her father’s food, but no lay person may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man eats a holy offering by mistake, he must add one-fifth to it and give the holy offering to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not profane the holy offerings which the Israelites contribute to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and so cause them to incur a penalty for guilt when they eat their holy offerings, for I am the Lord who sanctifies them.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelites and tell them, ‘When any man from the house of Israel or from the resident foreigners in Israel presents his offering for any of the votive or freewill offerings, which they present to the Lord as a burnt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: if it is to be acceptable for your benefit it must be a flawless male from the cattle, sheep, or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not present anything that has a flaw, because it will not be acceptable for your benefit.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man presents a peace-offering sacrifice to the Lord for a special votive offering or for a freewill offering from the herd or the flock, it must be flawless to be acceptable; it must have no flaw.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not present to the Lord something blind, or with a broken bone, or mutilated, or with a running sore, or with a festering eruption, or with a feverish rash. You must not give any of these as a gift on the altar to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for an ox or a sheep with a limb too long or stunted, you may present it as a freewill offering, but it will not be acceptable for a votive offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not present to the Lord something with testicles that are bruised, crushed, torn, or cut off; you must not do this in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even from a foreigner you must not present the food of your God from such animals as these, for they are ruined and flawed; they will not be acceptable for your benefit.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When an ox, lamb, or goat is born, it must be under the care of its mother seven days, but from the eighth day onward it will be acceptable as an offering gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not slaughter an ox or a sheep and its young on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you sacrifice a thanksgiving offering to the Lord, you must sacrifice it so that it is acceptable for your benefit.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that very day it must be eaten; you must not leave any part of it over until morning. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must be sure to do my commandments. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not profane my holy name, and I will be sanctified in the midst of the Israelites. I am the Lord who sanctifies you,
speaker: Narrator

text: the one who brought you out from the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘These are the Lord’s appointed times which you must proclaim as holy assemblies—my appointed times.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Six days work may be done, but on the seventh day there must be a Sabbath of complete rest, a holy assembly. You must not do any work; it is a Sabbath to the Lord in all the places where you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘These are the Lord’s appointed times, holy assemblies, which you must proclaim at their appointed time.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, at twilight, is a Passover offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the fifteenth day of the same month will be the Feast of Unleavened Bread to the Lord; seven days you must eat unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day there will be a holy assembly for you; you must not do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must present a gift to the Lord for seven days, and the seventh day is a holy assembly; you must not do any regular work.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When you enter the land that I am about to give to you and you gather in its harvest, then you must bring the sheaf of the first portion of your harvest to the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he must wave the sheaf before the Lord to be accepted for your benefit—on the day after the Sabbath the priest is to wave it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day you wave the sheaf you must also offer a flawless yearling lamb for a burnt offering to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with its grain offering, two-tenths of an ephah of choice wheat flour mixed with olive oil, as a gift to the Lord, a soothing aroma, and its drink offering, one-fourth of a hin of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat bread, roasted grain, or fresh grain until this very day, until you bring the offering to your God. This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all the places where you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must count for yourselves seven weeks from the day after the Sabbath, from the day you bring the wave offering sheaf; they must be complete weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must count fifty days—until the day after the seventh Sabbath—and then you must present a new grain offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the places where you live you must bring two loaves of bread for a wave offering; they must be made from two-tenths of an ephah of fine wheat flour, baked with yeast, as firstfruits to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with the loaves of bread, you must also present seven flawless yearling lambs, one young bull, and two rams. They are to be a burnt offering to the Lord along with their grain offering and drink offerings, a gift of a soothing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must also offer one male goat for a sin offering and two yearling lambs for a peace-offering sacrifice,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest is to wave them—the two lambs—along with the bread of the firstfruits, as a wave offering before the Lord; they will be holy to the Lord for the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On this very day you must proclaim an assembly; it is to be a holy assembly for you. You must not do any regular work. This is a perpetual statute in all the places where you live throughout your generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you gather in the harvest of your land, you must not completely harvest the corner of your field, and you must not gather up the gleanings of your harvest. You must leave them for the poor and the resident foreigner. I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you must have a complete rest, a memorial announced by loud horn blasts, a holy assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do any regular work, but you must present a gift to the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. It is to be a holy assembly for you, and you must humble yourselves and present a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do any work on this particular day, because it is a day of atonement to make atonement for yourselves before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, any person who does not behave with humility on this particular day will be cut off from his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for any person who does any work on this particular day, I will exterminate that person from the midst of his people—
speaker: Narrator

text: you must not do any work! This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all the places where you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a Sabbath of complete rest for you, and you must humble yourselves on the ninth day of the month in the evening, from evening until evening you must observe your Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘On the fifteenth day of this seventh month is the Feast of Shelters for seven days to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day is a holy assembly; you must do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you must present a gift to the Lord. On the eighth day there is to be a holy assembly for you, and you must present a gift to the Lord. It is a solemn assembly day; you must not do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘These are the appointed times of the Lord that you must proclaim as holy assemblies to present a gift to the Lord—burnt offering, grain offering, sacrifice, and drink offerings, each day according to its regulation,
speaker: Narrator

text: besides the Sabbaths of the Lord and all your gifts, votive offerings, and freewill offerings which you must give to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you gather in the produce of the land, you must celebrate a pilgrim festival of the Lord for seven days. On the first day is a complete rest and on the eighth day is complete rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day you must take for yourselves branches from majestic trees—palm branches, branches of leafy trees, and willows of the brook—and you must rejoice before the Lord your God for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must celebrate it as a pilgrim festival to the Lord for seven days in the year. This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations; you must celebrate it in the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must live in temporary shelters for seven days; every native citizen in Israel must live in shelters,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your future generations may know that I made the Israelites live in shelters when I brought them out from the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites about the appointed times of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command the Israelites to bring to you pure oil of beaten olives for the light, to make a lamp burn continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Outside the special curtain of the congregation in the Meeting Tent, Aaron must arrange it from evening until morning before the Lord continually. This is a perpetual statute throughout your generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ceremonially pure lampstand he must arrange the lamps before the Lord continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must take choice wheat flour and bake twelve loaves; there must be two-tenths of an ephah of flour in each loaf,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you must set them in two rows, six in a row, on the ceremonially pure table before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must put pure frankincense on each row, and it will become a memorial portion for the bread, a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each Sabbath day Aaron must arrange it before the Lord continually; this portion is from the Israelites as a perpetual covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will belong to Aaron and his sons, and they must eat it in a holy place because it is most holy to him, a perpetually-allotted portion from the gifts of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now an Israelite woman’s son whose father was an Egyptian went out among the Israelites, and the Israelite woman’s son and an Israelite man had a fight in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite woman’s son misused the Name and cursed, so they brought him to Moses. (Now his mother’s name was Shelomith, daughter of Dibri, of the tribe of Dan.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So they placed him in custody until they were able to make a clear legal decision for themselves based on words from the mouth of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring the one who cursed outside the camp, and all who heard him are to lay their hands on his head, and the whole congregation is to stone him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you are to tell the Israelites, ‘If any man curses his God he will bear responsibility for his sin,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one who misuses the name of the Lord must surely be put to death. The whole congregation must surely stone him, whether he is a resident foreigner or a native citizen; when he misuses the Name he must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man beats any person to death, he must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: One who beats an animal to death must make restitution for it, life for life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man inflicts an injury on his fellow citizen, just as he has done it must be done to him—
speaker: Narrator

text: fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth—just as he inflicts an injury on another person that same injury must be inflicted on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One who beats an animal to death must make restitution for it, but one who beats a person to death must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be one regulation for you, whether a resident foreigner or a native citizen, for I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses spoke to the Israelites and they brought the one who cursed outside the camp and stoned him with stones. So the Israelites did just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses at Mount Sinai:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When you enter the land that I am giving you, the land must observe a Sabbath to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six years you may sow your field, and six years you may prune your vineyard and gather the produce,
speaker: Narrator

text: but in the seventh year the land must have a Sabbath of complete rest—a Sabbath to the Lord. You must not sow your field or prune your vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not gather in the aftergrowth of your harvest and you must not pick the grapes of your unpruned vines; the land must have a year of complete rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may have the Sabbath produce of the land to eat—you, your male servant, your female servant, your hired worker, the resident foreigner who stays with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: your cattle, and the wild animals that are in your land—all its produce will be for you to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must count off seven weeks of years, seven times seven years, and the days of the seven weeks of years will amount to forty-nine years.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must sound loud horn blasts—in the seventh month, on the tenth day of the month, on the Day of Atonement—you must sound the horn in your entire land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must consecrate the fiftieth year, and you must proclaim a release in the land for all its inhabitants. That year will be your Jubilee; each one of you must return to his property and each one of you must return to his clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: That fiftieth year will be your Jubilee; you must not sow the land, harvest its aftergrowth, or pick the grapes of its unpruned vines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because that year is a Jubilee, it will be holy to you—you may eat its produce from the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘In this Year of Jubilee you must each return to your property.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you make a sale to your fellow citizen or buy from your fellow citizen, no one is to wrong his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may buy it from your fellow citizen according to the number of years since the last Jubilee; he may sell it to you according to the years of produce that are left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The more years there are, the more you may make its purchase price, and the fewer years there are, the less you must make its purchase price, because he is only selling to you a number of years of produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one is to oppress his fellow citizen, but you must fear your God, because I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must obey my statutes and my regulations; you must be sure to keep them so that you may live securely in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘The land will give its fruit and you may eat until you are satisfied, and you may live securely in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you say, “What will we eat in the seventh year if we do not sow and gather our produce?”
speaker: Narrator

text: I will command my blessing for you in the sixth year so that it may yield the produce for three years,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you may sow the eighth year and eat from that sixth year’s produce—old produce. Until you bring in the ninth year’s produce, you may eat old produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land must not be sold without reclaim because the land belongs to me, for you are foreign residents, temporary settlers, with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all your landed property you must provide for the right of redemption of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If your brother becomes impoverished and sells some of his property, his near redeemer is to come to you and redeem what his brother sold.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has no redeemer, but he prospers and gains enough for its redemption,
speaker: Narrator

text: he is to calculate the value of the years it was sold, refund the balance to the man to whom he had sold it, and return to his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has not prospered enough to refund a balance to him, then what he sold will belong to the one who bought it until the Jubilee year, but it must revert in the Jubilee and the original owner may return to his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man sells a residential house in a walled city, its right of redemption must extend until one full year from its sale; its right of redemption must extend to a full calendar year.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is not redeemed before the full calendar year is ended, the house in the walled city will belong without reclaim to the one who bought it throughout his generations; it will not revert in the Jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: The houses of villages, however, which have no wall surrounding them must be considered as the field of the land; they will have the right of redemption and must revert in the Jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the cities of the Levites, the houses in the cities which they possess, the Levites must have a perpetual right of redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever someone among the Levites might redeem—the sale of a house which is his property in a city—must revert in the Jubilee, because the houses of the cities of the Levites are their property in the midst of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the open field areas of their cities must not be sold, because that is their perpetual possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If your brother becomes impoverished and is indebted to you, you must support him; he must live with you like a foreign resident.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take interest or profit from him, but you must fear your God and your brother must live with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not lend him your money at interest and you must not sell him food for profit.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God who brought you out from the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan—to be your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If your brother becomes impoverished with regard to you so that he sells himself to you, you must not subject him to slave service.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must be with you as a hired worker, as a resident foreigner; he must serve with you until the Year of Jubilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: but then he may go free, he and his children with him, and may return to his family and to the property of his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Israelites are my servants whom I brought out from the land of Egypt, they must not be sold in a slave sale.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not rule over them harshly, but you must fear your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As for your male and female slaves who may belong to you—you may buy male and female slaves from the nations all around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, you may buy slaves from the children of the foreigners who reside with you, and from their families that are with you, whom they have fathered in your land; they may become your property.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may give them as an inheritance to your children after you to possess as property. You may enslave them perpetually. However, as for your brothers the Israelites, no man may rule over his brother harshly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a resident foreigner who is with you prospers and your brother becomes impoverished with regard to him so that he sells himself to a resident foreigner who is with you or to a member of a foreigner’s family,
speaker: Narrator

text: after he has sold himself he retains a right of redemption. One of his brothers may redeem him,
speaker: Narrator

text: or his uncle or his cousin may redeem him, or any one of the rest of his blood relatives—his family—may redeem him, or if he prospers he may redeem himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must calculate with the one who bought him the number of years from the year he sold himself to him until the Jubilee year, and the cost of his sale must correspond to the number of years, according to the rate of wages a hired worker would have earned while with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are still many years, in keeping with them he must refund most of the cost of his purchase for his redemption,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if only a few years remain until the Jubilee, he must calculate for himself in keeping with the remaining years and refund it for his redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must be with the one who bought him like a yearly hired worker. The one who bought him must not rule over him harshly in your sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, he is not redeemed in these ways, he must go free in the Jubilee year, he and his children with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Israelites are my own servants; they are my servants whom I brought out from the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must not make for yourselves idols, so you must not set up for yourselves a carved image or a pillar, and you must not place a sculpted stone in your land to bow down before it, for I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must keep my Sabbaths and reverence my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If you walk in my statutes and are sure to obey my commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you your rains in their time so that the land will give its yield and the trees of the field will produce their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Threshing season will extend for you until the season for harvesting grapes, and the season for harvesting grapes will extend until sowing season, so you will eat your bread until you are satisfied, and you will live securely in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will grant peace in the land so that you will lie down to sleep without anyone terrifying you. I will remove harmful animals from the land, and no sword of war will pass through your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will pursue your enemies and they will fall before you by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of you will pursue a hundred, and a hundred of you will pursue ten thousand, and your enemies will fall before you by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn to you, make you fruitful, multiply you, and maintain my covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will still be eating stored produce from the previous year and will have to clean out what is stored from the previous year to make room for new.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘I will put my tabernacle in your midst and I will not abhor you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will walk among you, and I will be your God and you will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God who brought you out from the land of Egypt, from being their slaves, and I broke the bars of your yoke and caused you to walk upright.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If, however, you do not obey me and keep all these commandments—
speaker: Narrator

text: if you reject my statutes and abhor my regulations so that you do not keep all my commandments and you break my covenant—
speaker: Narrator

text: I for my part will do this to you: I will inflict horror on you, consumption and fever, which diminish eyesight and drain away the vitality of life. You will sow your seed in vain because your enemies will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against you. You will be struck down before your enemies, those who hate you will rule over you, and you will flee when there is no one pursuing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If, in spite of all these things, you do not obey me, I will discipline you seven times more on account of your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will break your strong pride and make your sky like iron and your land like bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your strength will be used up in vain, your land will not give its yield, and the trees of the land will not produce their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If you walk in hostility against me and are not willing to obey me, I will increase your affliction seven times according to your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send the wild animals against you and they will bereave you of your children, annihilate your cattle, and diminish your population so that your roads will become deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If in spite of these things you do not allow yourselves to be disciplined and you walk in hostility against me,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I myself will also walk in hostility against you and strike you seven times on account of your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring on you an avenging sword, a covenant vengeance. Although you will gather together into your cities, I will send pestilence among you and you will be given into enemy hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I break off your supply of bread, ten women will bake your bread in one oven; they will ration your bread by weight, and you will eat and not be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If in spite of this you do not obey me but walk in hostility against me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will walk in hostile rage against you and I myself will also discipline you seven times on account of your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat the flesh of your sons and the flesh of your daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy your high places and cut down your incense altars, and I will stack your dead bodies on top of the lifeless bodies of your idols. I will abhor you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will lay your cities waste and make your sanctuaries desolate, and I will refuse to smell your soothing aromas.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will make the land desolate and your enemies who live in it will be appalled.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter you among the nations and unsheathe the sword after you, so your land will become desolate and your cities will become a waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then the land will make up for its Sabbaths all the days it lies desolate while you are in the land of your enemies; then the land will rest and make up its Sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days of the desolation it will have the rest it did not have on your Sabbaths when you lived on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As for the ones who remain among you, I will bring despair into their hearts in the lands of their enemies. The sound of a blowing leaf will pursue them, and they will flee as one who flees the sword and will fall down even though there is no pursuer.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will stumble over each other as those who flee before a sword, though there is no pursuer, and there will be no one to take a stand for you before your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will perish among the nations; the land of your enemies will consume you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As for the ones who remain among you, they will rot away because of their iniquity in the lands of your enemies, and they will also rot away because of their ancestors’ iniquities which are with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, when they confess their iniquity and their ancestors’ iniquities which they committed by trespassing against me, by which they also walked in hostility against me
speaker: Narrator

text: (and I myself will walk in hostility against them and bring them into the land of their enemies), and then their uncircumcised hearts become humbled and they make up for their iniquities,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember my covenant with Jacob and also my covenant with Isaac and also my covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land will be abandoned by them in order that it may make up for its Sabbaths while it is made desolate without them, and they will make up for their iniquity because they have rejected my regulations and have abhorred my statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In spite of this, however, when they are in the land of their enemies I will not reject them and abhor them to make a complete end of them, to break my covenant with them, for I am the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember for them the covenant with their ancestors whom I brought out from the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations to be their God. I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the statutes, regulations, and instructions which the Lord established between himself and the Israelites at Mount Sinai through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When a man makes a special votive offering based on the conversion value of a person to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: the conversion value of the male from twenty years old up to sixty years old is fifty shekels by the standard of the sanctuary shekel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person is a female, the conversion value is thirty shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person is from five years old up to twenty years old, the conversion value of the male is twenty shekels, and for the female ten shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person is one month old up to five years old, the conversion value of the male is five shekels of silver, and for the female the conversion value is three shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person is from sixty years old and older, if he is a male the conversion value is fifteen shekels, and for the female ten shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person making the votive offering is too poor to pay the conversion value, he must stand the person before the priest and the priest will establish his conversion value; according to what the man who made the votive offering can afford, the priest will establish his conversion value.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If what is vowed is a kind of animal from which an offering may be presented to the Lord, anything which he gives to the Lord from this kind of animal will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not replace or exchange it, good for bad or bad for good, and if he does indeed exchange one animal for another animal, then both the original animal and its substitute will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If what is vowed is an unclean animal from which an offering must not be presented to the Lord, then he must stand the animal before the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priest will establish its conversion value, whether good or bad. According to the conversion value assessed by the priest, thus it will be.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the person who made the vow redeems the animal, he must add one-fifth to its conversion value.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man consecrates his house as holy to the Lord, the priest will establish its conversion value, whether good or bad. Just as the priest establishes its conversion value, thus it will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the one who consecrates it redeems his house, he must add to it one-fifth of its conversion value in silver, and it will belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If a man consecrates to the Lord some of his own landed property, the conversion value must be calculated in accordance with the amount of seed needed to sow it, a homer of barley seed being priced at fifty shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he consecrates his field in the Jubilee year, the conversion value will stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if he consecrates his field after the Jubilee, the priest will calculate the price for him according to the years that are left until the next Jubilee year, and it will be deducted from the conversion value.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the one who consecrated the field redeems it, he must add to it one-fifth of the conversion price and it will belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he does not redeem the field, but sells the field to someone else, he may never redeem it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it reverts in the Jubilee, the field will be holy to the Lord like a permanently dedicated field; it will become the priest’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If he consecrates to the Lord a field he has purchased, which is not part of his own landed property,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will calculate for him the amount of its conversion value until the Jubilee year, and he must pay the conversion value on that Jubilee day as something that is holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the Jubilee year the field will return to the one from whom he bought it, the one to whom it belongs as landed property.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every conversion value must be calculated by the standard of the sanctuary shekel; twenty gerahs to the shekel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Surely no man may consecrate a firstborn that already belongs to the Lord as a firstborn among the animals; whether it is an ox or a sheep, it belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, it is among the unclean animals, he may ransom it according to its conversion value and must add one-fifth to it, but if it is not redeemed it must be sold according to its conversion value.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Surely anything that a man permanently dedicates to the Lord from all that belongs to him, whether from people, animals, or his landed property, must be neither sold nor redeemed; anything permanently dedicated is most holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any human being who is permanently dedicated to the Lord must not be ransomed; such a person must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Any tithe of the land, from the grain of the land or from the fruit of the trees, belongs to the Lord; it is holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man redeems part of his tithe, however, he must add one-fifth to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the tithe of herds or flocks, everything which passes under the rod, the tenth one will be holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The owner must not examine the animals to distinguish between good and bad, and he must not exchange it. If, however, he does exchange it, both the original animal and its substitute will be holy and must not be redeemed.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the commandments which the Lord commanded Moses to tell the Israelites at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator
